image.altText: A composite image of a young man in black and white and an older man smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Iraklis Roussos — a pack-a-day smoker — died of lung cancer in 2019. A judge has ruled the asbestos Mr Roussos was exposed to while working on dust-choked building sites for much of his life materially contributed to his disease.

title.children: Builder's family awarded damages in asbestos lung cancer case against Amaca

image.altText: The interior of the Singapore Airlines plane

props.synopsis: A 73-year-old British man has died and dozens are injured after a Singapore Airlines flight from London struck "severe turbulence" and was forced to make an emergency landing in Bangkok.

title.children: Man dead after severe turbulence on London-Singapore flight carrying 56 Australians

image.altText: Cluttered shelves line a wall above a bench lined with black plastic. A blender and kitchen mixer are on the bench.

props.synopsis: The government will ban compounding pharmacists from making replica versions of diabetes drugs like Ozempic and Mounjaro, widely used off-label for weight loss, amid public safety concerns.

title.children: 'Risk to public safety': Raid reveals unregulated Ozempic made in filthy conditions

image.altText: A close up shot of Peter Dutton in glasses.

props.synopsis: In using his budget reply to rail against foreign investors buying up existing properties, Peter Dutton almost made a case that could really help first homebuyers.

title.children: Peter Dutton has spelled out the maths on home ownership — and he might have done us a favour

image.altText: A photo showing a women wearing pink dress about to talk

props.synopsis: One month after the Alice Springs youth curfew, leaders say there's been very little consultation with frontline youth services as the government prepares to pass laws making it easier to impose curfews across the territory.

title.children: 'That's not important to me': Youth services not consulted over curfew laws

image.altText: A grand looking building is surrounded by palm trees.

props.synopsis: New laws that allow the NT police commissioner to declare snap curfews in response to social unrest have passed through parliament, despite concerns from some that they amount to government overreach.

title.children: Controversial curfew laws have passed NT Parliament. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: George Clooney with a grey beard smiles off camera while his wife Amal Clooney with long brown hair smiles.

props.synopsis: Amal Clooney is arguably one of the most famous faces of human rights law. However, social media users grew frustrated in recent months by what they claimed was her silence on the Israel-Gaza war. Those critics have now been silenced.

title.children: Amal Clooney has silenced her critics after revealing her secret involvement with the ICC

image.altText: PaTH scheme

props.synopsis: Whenever mass sackings are announced, like the one at Telstra, it's only natural to wonder if it's isolated to one firm or part of a growing trend within corporate Australia.

title.children: Is the Telstra mass sacking a worrying sign of things to come?

image.altText: A picture of a home with a for sale sign out the front.

props.synopsis: A Queensland landlord says he has been left thousands of dollars out of pocket trying to evict renters who refused to leave after their contract was up, delaying the sale of the house.

title.children: Landlord spends thousands in 'awfully challenging' bid to evict tenants on expired lease

image.altText: The entrance to a tunnel with a concrete floor, surrouned by industrial equipment.

props.synopsis: It is unclear when the machine will be able to get moving again and if it will impact plans for Snowy 2.0 to begin operations in late 2027.

title.children: Snowy 2.0 faces fresh problems, with tunnel boring machine Florence stuck yet again

image.altText: A graphic showing nuclear chimneys blowing dollars behind renewable energy sources such as wind and solar

props.synopsis: Building a large-scale nuclear power plant in Australia would cost at least $8.5 billion, take 15 years to deliver and produce electricity at roughly twice the cost of renewable sources, the country's leading scientific institution has found.

title.children: A nuclear power plant for Australia would cost at least $8.5 billion and take 15 years to deliver, new CSIRO report shows

image.altText: A composite image of Meng Wong standing outside of Suncorp bank, and a bank invoice for 80 thousand dollars.

props.synopsis: False documentation might be one of the oldest scams in the book but scammers are now able to fake being a company more easily — and Australians are falling for it.

title.children: Australians are still losing millions to this type of scam. Meng lost $80,000 and wants banks to do more

image.altText: A large aeroplane sits with its back door open on the tarmac as people with bags walk toward it

props.synopsis: More than 100 Australians and other tourists stranded for up to a week in the violence in New Caledonia have been repatriated.

title.children: 'Thank God!' Australians relieved as first evacuation flights land after mission to riot-stricken New Caledonia

image.altText: A woman in a blouse stands looking seriously at the camera.

props.synopsis: Indigenous experts say Australia will fail to reach a major Closing the Gap target unless First Nations domestic violence services are given more support.

title.children: First Nations experts say Closing the Gap family violence target will not be met without more funding

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in a blue suit behind a desk in a court room. A security guard stands behind him. His lawyer sits next to him.

props.synopsis: After weeks of speculation about whether he would take the stand to defend himself, the former president opts not to testify, clearing the way for jurors to start deliberating the historic trial next week.

title.children: Donald Trump opts not to take to witness stand, bringing testimonies in hush money trial to an end

image.altText: A man and a teenage boy take a selfie together on the red carpet.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian teenager has scored a speaking role in what's shaping up to be this year's biggest Hollywood blockbuster, Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga, despite only auditioning as an extra.

title.children: 'Look … he's gonna get a part': Mad Max director casts Tasmanian teen in speaking role for Furiosa

image.altText: a headshot of a man with grey hair and glasses smiling at camera

props.synopsis: His autopsy, released in December, found that the amount of ketamine in Perry's blood was in the range used for general anaesthesia during surgery.

title.children: Investigation into Matthew Perry's death to probe amount of ketamine in blood

image.altText: The back of a woman with curly blond hair standing on the street.

props.synopsis: Homeless services are seeing more employed people accessing their services and say single mothers fleeing domestic violence are particularly vulnerable.

title.children: How single mothers face a 'triple whammy' in the housing crisis

image.altText: A sleepy koala rests on a branch high up in a tree.

props.synopsis: Koalas are easy to identify, but really hard to spot. To help conserve the species, citizen science is being used on a national scale for the first time to collect important information on koala numbers, habitat and health.

title.children: Jackson has done more than 70 koala surveys over three years. He's only found five koalas

image.altText: Three people commute in a small metal boat on calm ocean in front of villas that sit on a green mountainside close to the ocean

props.synopsis: The UN maritime court ruled in favour of nine island states who had sought greater protection from the impacts of climate change.

title.children: World-first ruling finds states need to mitigate the effects of carbon dioxide on oceans

image.altText: Anonymous woman lies in a bed with heart rate monitor clipped on finger at the Marie Stopes clinic in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: Health staff across Victoria say women are being blocked from accessing abortion services by conscientious objectors, who are then failing to refer them to alternative providers.

title.children: 'We don't do that kind of thing here': Advocates say women are struggling to access abortion services

image.altText: Three members of Paramore in a dark room. Hayley Williams wears an oversized jacket like Talking Heads' David Byrne

props.synopsis: A new tribute to the Talking Heads' 1984 concert film Stop Making Sense offers something for fans, old and new.

title.children: Miley Cyrus, Norah Jones, Lorde and more pay tribute to Talking Heads — do they do them justice?

image.altText: A couple smiles as they take a selfie.

props.synopsis: The federal regulator has taken action against two more doctors as part of an investigation into a clinic following the death of a woman soon after a surgical abortion at a health clinic in Melbourne's south-east.

title.children: Two more doctors suspended following investigation into Melbourne woman's death after abortion

image.altText: William Tyrrell in red shirt, sitting in chair with drink

props.synopsis: Detectives investigating the disappearance of toddler William Tyrrell have asked the prosecutors looking into the toddler's foster mother to suspend their inquiry until a coronial inquest resumes at the end of this year.

title.children: Police ask prosecutors to suspend inquiry into William Tyrrell's former foster mother

image.altText: Telstra Shop signage outside Brisbane CBD store

props.synopsis: Telstra reveals plans to sack up to 2,800 workers as part of its latest cost-cutting measures, with most of these job losses to occur by the end of this year.

title.children: Telstra's 'massive change' has 'blindsided' workers, but will it pay off for customers and shareholders?

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: The jury in Greg Lynn's murder trial hears slain camper Russell Hill hid his affair with childhood sweetheart Carol Clay by telling others they were first cousins.

title.children: Wife of slain Victorian camper did not know husband was still seeing secret lover when he disappeared, murder trial hears

image.altText: Rows of dead birds including skuas and penguins.

props.synopsis: A deadly strain of avian influenza has breached the world's most remote continent. Scientists say it's only a matter of time before it reaches Australia.

title.children: On the planet's most remote continent, a deadly virus is leaving a 'trail of destruction' that has scientists on edge

image.altText: Shot of steel gate with sign saying "Commonwealth of Australia"

props.synopsis: A former immigration detainee, released after the High Court ruled indefinite detention was unlawful, receives a suspended sentence for breaching his curfew and letting his GPS tracker's battery run out.

title.children: Ex-immigration detainee released back into community after failing to keep ankle monitor battery charged

image.altText: Man in black polo shirt in front of highway with blurred clouds behind

props.synopsis: For the first time since Richard Roe's car was found abandoned on the side of the Stuart Highway in 2016, his family has a chance to hear about his possible fate, as an inquest into his disappearance begins.

title.children: 'Is Richard buried at your property?' Explosive evidence heard in cold case missing man inquest

image.altText: An iPhone shows various apps against a black background.

props.synopsis: Many Australian consumers are unaware of the extent of personal data being collected about them on a day-to-day basis, says a new report.

title.children: It would take almost 46 hours to read every privacy policy you agree to in a month. Here's why that's concerning

image.altText: Bill Shorten At National Press Club

props.synopsis: As a parliamentary hearing kicks off into draft legislation paving the way for changes to the NDIS, a governmental stoush has re-emerged. Here's what's going on.

title.children: 'Get this right quickly': The governmental stoush over the NDIS explained

image.altText: A man wearing a Woolworths polo shirt with the name tag 'Brad' stands in a supermarket.

props.synopsis: Woolworths boss Brad Banducci has defended the amount of food the supermarket giant rejects with a top executive saying no one wants a banana that is "too big", a South Australian parliamentary inquiry has heard.

title.children: Woolworths CEO says supermarket contributes 'very little' to food waste
